instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
Hello my friend, I don't have this electrical scheme, but I imagine it looks or feels like <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I used it as a reference. No signs of oxidation, no image, cooler turns sometimes and the external ssd turns on the led. 
 

voltage:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13.0v; <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>; <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V; <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 20.2v; <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS_F</SIGNAL> 20.2; <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.21V; <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XB</SIGNAL> 3.31V; <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> 1.8V; <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.11V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> looks correct and you get even S0 volatges; why wasting time measuring USB-C area then?

So your board powers on, but doesn't work; there is a difference, don't get confused.

Check L7210/20 voltage.
Did you check for USB activity?

[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Wgr8exOQxJcQzhZV-N4PwlQbxhJ8tEB_/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
voltage: 
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_SW1</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G_PH1</SIGNAL> 0.98V; <SIGNAL>PP3V_S0</SIGNAL> 3.31V; <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> 1.81V; <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> 3.32V; <SIGNAL>P5VS0SW_CT2</SIGNAL>  9.95V.

Mac recognizes the external SSD, but the system that is on the ssd does not start. No image on external HDMI.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
The Link LED of external SSD adaptor flashes?
That is the sign to confirm USB activity...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: No. It just stays on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
Then is no USB activity.
BTW, get this
[URL unfurl="true"]http://www.cmizapper.com/products/usb-tester.html[/URL]
for the future.

Try known good BIOS...

threads.message: Coloquei esse BIOS que você me deu e ainda tem o mesmo defeito. A placa não apresenta sinais de oxidação, as tensões estão boas, não sei onde pode estar o problema, você já viu algum desses casos?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: I put this BIOS that you gave me and it still has the same defect. The plate has no signs of oxidation, the voltages are okay, I don't know where the problem may be, have you caught any cases like that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: <CHIP>U7370</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> are the hottest components in the thermal camera.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> when changing the USB-C port it does not have heating in the thermal camera, only the <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
You said USB adapter has light on.
Is that Link LED, or just power LED?
A normal USB adapter for SSD/HDD should have 2 LEDs...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: the two HDD leds are on, but the reading LED does not flash, so the HDD is not being read.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: May be bad CPU then...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message: <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> would not influence this HDD reading?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
I cannot find <CHIP>U7330</CHIP> in schematic.
Do you mean <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> instead?

Do you get correct voltage at L7370?
The board will not work without that voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01 no power
threads.message:
sorry, <CHIP>U7370</CHIP> the right. 
L7370  1.04V.
